editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: SInce you have done the Nation ≈øo much right, and you ‚Ä¢ ≈øelves ≈øo much honour as to declare that the People (under God) are the original of all ju≈øt Powers; and given us thereby fair grounds to hope, that you really intend their Freedom and Pro≈øperity; yet the way thereunto being frequently mi≈øtaken, and through ha≈øt or error of judgement, tho≈øe who me ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the be≈øt, are many times mi≈ø-led ≈øo far to the prejudice of tho≈øe that tru≈øt them, as to leave them in a condition neere≈øt to bondage, when they have thought they had brought them into a way of Freedom. And ≈øince woful experience hath manife≈øted this to be a Truth, there ≈øeemeth no ≈ømall rea≈øon that you ≈øhould ≈øeriou≈øly lay to heart what at pre≈øent we have to offer, for di≈øcovery and prevention of ≈øo great a danger.

And becau≈øe we have bin the fir≈øt movers in and concerning a ‚Ä¢
Agreement of the People, as the mo≈øt proper and ju≈øt means for the ≈øetling the long and tedious di≈øtractions of this Nation, occa≈øioned by nothing more, than the uncertainty of our government; and ≈øince there hath bin an Agreement prepared and pre≈øented by ≈øome Officers of the Army to this honourable Hou≈øe, as what they thought requi≈øite to be agreed unto by the People (you approving thereof) we ≈øhall in the fir≈øt place deliver our apprehen≈øions thereupon.

That an Agreement between tho≈øe that tru≈øt, and tho≈øe who are tru≈øted, hath appeared a thing acceptable to this honorable Hou≈øe,
his Excellency, and the Officers of the Army, is as much to our rejoycing, as we conceive it ju≈øt in it ≈øelf, and profitable for the Common-wealth, and cannot doubt but that you will protect tho≈øe of the people, who have no waies forfeited their Birth-right, in their proper liberty of taking this, or any other, as God and their own Con≈øiderationss ≈øhall direct them.

Which we the rather mention, for that many particulars in the Agreement before you, are upon ≈øerious examination thereof, di≈ø-≈øatisfactory to mo≈øt of tho≈øe who are very earne≈øtly de≈øirous of an Agreement, and many very material things ≈øeem to be wanting theren, which may be ≈øupplyed in another; As

1. They are now much troubled there ≈øhould be any Intervalls between he ending of this Repre≈øentative, and the begining of the next as being de≈øirous that this pre≈øent Parliament that hath ately done ≈øo great things in ≈øo ≈øhort a time, tending to their Liberties, ≈øhould ≈øit; until with certainty and ≈øafety they can ≈øee them deivered into the hands of another Repre≈øentative, rather than to eave them (though never ≈øo ≈ømall a time) under the dominion of a Councel of State; a Con≈øtitution of a new and unexperienced Nature, and which they fear, as the ca≈øe now ≈øtands, may de≈øign to perpetuate their power, and to keep off Parliaments for ever.

2. They now conceive no le≈øs danger, in that it is provided that Parliaments for the future are to continue but 6. moneths, and a Councel of State 18. In which time, if they ≈øhould prove corrupt, having command of all Forces by Sea and Land, they will have great opportunities to make them≈øelves ab≈øolute and unaccountable: And becau≈øe this is a danger, than which there cannot well be a greater; they generally incline to Annual Parliaments, bounded and limited as rea≈øon ≈øhall devi≈øe, not di≈ø≈øolvable, but to be continued or adjourned as ≈øhall ≈øeem good in their di≈øcretion, during that yeer, but no longer; and then to di≈ø≈øolve of cour≈øe, and give way to tho≈øe who ≈øhall be cho≈øen immediatly to ≈øucceed them, and in the Intervals of their adjournments, to entru≈øt an ordinary Committee of their own members, as in other ca≈øes limited and bounded with expre≈øs in≈øtructions, and accountable to the next Se≈ø≈øion, which will avoid all tho≈øe dangers feared from a Councel of State, as at pre≈øent this is con≈øtituted.

3. They are not ≈øatisfied with the clau≈øe, whereas it is ≈øaid, that
the power of the Repre≈øentative ≈øhall „Äà‚óä„Äâ to the erecting and aboli≈øhing of Courts of Iu≈øtice; ≈øince the alteration of the u≈øual way of Tryals by twelve ≈øworn men of the Neighborhood, may be included therein: a con≈øtitution ≈øo equal and ju≈øt in it ≈øelf, as that they conceive it ought to remain unalterable. Neither is it cleer what is meant by the≈øe words, (viz.) That the Repre≈øentatives have the highe≈øt final judgement. They conceiving that their Authority in the≈øe ca≈øes, is onely to make Laws, Rules, and Directions for other Courts and Per≈øon; a≈ø≈øigned by Law for the execution thereof, unto which every member of the Common-wealth, as well tho≈øe of the Repre≈øentative, as others, ≈øhould be alike ≈øubject; it being likewi≈øe unrea≈øonable in it ≈øelf, and an occa≈øion of much partiality, inju≈øtice, and vexation to the people, that the Law-makers, ≈øhould be Law-executors.

4. Although it doth provide that in the Laws hereafter to be made, no per≈øon by vertue of any Tenure, Grant, Charter, Parent, Degree, or Birth, ≈øhall be priviledged from ≈øubjection thereunto, or from being bound thereby, as well as others; Yet doth it not null and make void tho≈øe pre≈øent Protections by Law, or otherwi≈øe; nor leave all per≈øons, as well Lords as others, alike liable in per≈øon and e≈øtate, as in rea≈øon and con≈øcience they ought to be.

5. They are very much un≈øatisfied with what is expre≈øt as a re≈øerve from the Repre≈øentative, in matters of Religion, as being very ob≈øcure, and full of perplexity, that ought to be mo≈øt plain and clear; there having occurred no greater trouble to the Nation about any thing than by the intermedling of Parliaments in matters of Religion.

6. They ≈øeem to conceive it ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary, that there be in their Agreement, a re≈øerve from ever having any Kingly Government, and a bar again≈øt re≈øtoring the Hou≈øe of Lords, both which are wanting in the Agreement which is before you.

7. They ≈øeem to be re≈øolved to take away all known and burden≈øome grievances, as Tythes, that great oppre≈ø≈øion of the Countries indu≈øtry and hindrance of Tillage: Exci≈øe, and Cu≈øtoms, Tho≈øe ≈øecret thieves, and Robbers, Drainers of the poor and middle ≈øort of People, and the greate≈øt Ob≈øtructers of Trade, ≈øurmounting all the prejudices of Ship-mony, Pattents, and Projects, before this Parliament: al≈øo to take away all Monopolizing Companies of Marchants, the hinderers and decayers of Clothing
and Cloth-working, Dying, and the like u≈øeful profe≈ø≈øions; by which thou≈øands of poor people might be ≈øet at work, that are now ready to ≈øtarve, were Marchandizing re≈øtored to its due and proper freedom: they conceive likewi≈øe that the three grievances before mentioned, (viz.) Monopolizing Companies, Exci≈øe, and Cu≈øtomes, do exceedingly prejudice Shiping, and Navigation, and Con≈øequently di≈øcourage Sea-men, and Marriners, and which have had no ≈ømal influence upon the late unhappy revolts which have ≈øo much endangered the Nation, and ≈øo much advantaged your enemies. They al≈øo incline to direct a more equal and le≈ø≈øe burden≈øome way for levying monies for the future, tho≈øe other fore-mentioned being ≈øo chargable in the receipt, as that the very ≈øtipends and allowance to the Officers attending thereupon would defray a very great part of the charge of the Army; whereas now they engender and ≈øupport a corrupt intere≈øt. They al≈øo have in mind to take away all impri≈øonment of di≈øabled men, for debt; and to provide ≈øome effectual cour≈øe to enforce all that are able to a ≈øpeedy payment, and not ≈øuffer them to be ≈øheltered in Pri≈øons, where they live in plenty, whil≈øt their Creditors are undone. They have al≈øo in mind to provide work, and comfortable maintainance for all ≈øorts of poor, aged, and impotent people, and to e≈øtabli≈øh ≈øome more ≈øpeedy, le≈ø≈øe trouble≈øome and chargeable way for deciding of Controver≈øies in Law, whole families having been ruined by ≈øeeking right in the wayes yet in being: All which (though of greate≈øt and mo≈øt immediate concernment to the People, are yet omitted in their Agreement before you.

The≈øe and the like are their intentions in what they purpo≈øe for an Agreement of the People, as being re≈øolved (≈øo far as they are able) to lay an impo≈ø≈øibility upon all whom they ≈øhall hereafter tru≈øt, of ever wronging the Common wealth in any con≈øiderable mea≈øure, without certainty of ruining them≈øelves, and as conceiving it to be an improper tedious, and unprofitable thing for the People, to be ever runing after their Repre≈øentatives with Petitions for redre≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch Grievances as may at once be removed by them≈øelves, or to depend for the≈øe things ≈øo e≈ø≈øential to their happine≈ø≈øe and freedom, upon the uncertain judgements of ≈øeveral Repre≈øentatives, the one being apt to renew what the other hath taken away.

And as to the u≈øe of their Rights and Liberties herein as becometh,
and is due to the people, from whom all ju≈øt powers are derived; they hoped for and expect what protection is in you and the Army to afford: and we likewi≈øe in their and our own behalfe do earne≈øtly de≈øire, that you will publikely declare your re≈øolution to protect tho≈øe who have not forfeited their liberties in the u≈øe thereof, le≈øt they ≈øhould conceive that the Agreement before you being publi≈øhed abroad, and the Commi≈ø≈øioners therein nominated being at work in per≈øuance thereof, is intended to be impo≈øed upon them, which as it is ab≈øolutely contrary to the nature of a free Agreement, ≈øo we are per≈øwaded it cannot enter into your thoughts to u≈øe any impul≈øion therein.

But although we have pre≈øented our apprehen≈øions and de≈øires concerning this great work of an Agreement, and are apt to per≈øwade our ≈øelves that nothing ≈øhall be able to fru≈øtrate our hopes which we have built thereupon; yet have we ≈øeen and heard many things of late, which occa≈øions not only apprehen≈øions of other matters intended to be brought upon us of danger to ≈øuch an Agreement, but of bondage and ruine to all ≈øuch as ≈øhall pur≈øue it.

In≈øomuch that we are even aga≈øt and a≈øtoni≈øhed to ≈øee that notwith≈øtanding the productions of the highe≈øt notions of freedom that ever this Nation, or any people in the world, have brought to light, notwith≈øtanding the va≈øt expece of blood and trea≈øure that hath been made to purcha≈øe tho≈øe freedoms, notwith≈øtanding the many eminent and even miraculous Victories God hath been plea≈øed to honour our ju≈øt Cau≈øe withall, notwith≈øtanding the extraordinary gripes and pangs, this Hou≈øe hath ≈øuffered more than once at the hands of your own ≈øervants, and that at lea≈øt ≈øeemingly for the obtaining the≈øe our Native Liberties.
